Article Title: The Coated Salted Paper Prints from the Eduard Isaac Asser Collection at the Rijksmuseum: FTIR and OCT Identification and Characterization
Author(s): Tom Callewaert-Dore, Rosina Herrera Garrido, Suzan de Groot
Journal: Journal of the American Institute for Conservation
Data Collected: ourier transform infraredspectroscopy (FTIR) helped us to identify, to a certain extent, the nature of the coatings. Beforethe analysis, the prints had been described either as “shellac coated” or as “waxed,” based ontheir varying degree of sheen. FTIR identiﬁed a larger number of substances in the coatings:gum, protein, natural resin, and possibly starch. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) was alsoused to study the coatings. Number of salted paper prints present in the albums. FTIR analysis results. Extrapolation of FTIR results (type of coating). Comparison of diﬀerent coatings and their surfaces. FTIR spectrum of RP-F-AB12279-AL, showing the albumen and natural resin peaks.

Article Title: Beauty Revealed: Technical Analysis and Treatment of Zand and Qajar Oil Paintings
Author(s): Melissa Gardner, Corina E Rogge (https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8154-922X)
Journal: Journal of the American Institute for Conservation
Data Collected: x-radiography, infrared reﬂectography, and macro-area x-rayﬂuorescence spectroscopy. Selective microscopic sampling enabled pigment and binderidentiﬁcation using Raman and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and scanning electronmicroscopy coupled with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy. All paintings are oil on cottoncanvas and utilize a limited palette that includes Prussian blue, orpiment, and vermillion. Fourpaintings contain copper alloy leaf used to simulate gold jewelry and textiles. Summary of pigments and materials found in the Zand and Qajar paintings through XRF, SEM-EDX, FTIR, and Ramanspectroscopies. X-radiograph Standing Woman Holding a Glass of Wine. Diagram showing the diﬀerent canvas sections piecedtogether to create the support. Map of the arsenicsignal, after deconvolution and subtraction of lead. Elemental distribution maps obtained by MA-XRF showing mercury in red, and the arsenic signal, after deconvolution andsubtraction of lead
Data Collected (AAT): X-radiography; Wave-length Dispersive X-ray Fluorescence Spectroscopy (XRF); Electron Microscopy; Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR)
Art Historical and/or Cultural Object of: Hossein Afshar Collection, Museum of Fine Arts, Houston

Article Title: Géricault's Lion Devouring a Horse Stone Paper Matrix: Technical Study
Author(s): Katherine Eremin, Georgina Rayner, Christina Taylor, Christopher Wallace
Journal: Journal of the American Institute for Conservation
Data Collected: X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis of the stone paper coating revealed the presence of lead and the absence of calcium, whereas previously published stone paper recipes all included calcium. Small samples were taken for analysis which confirmed that the material was dominated by lead white (basic lead carbonate) combined with a drying oil binder, casein and gum. Stone paper mockups revealed that the addition of casein was crucial to forming a resistant, stable coating for printing, but it also formed a brittle film, and casein was likely a contributing factor to the development of losses in the image during printing. Etch tests carried out on mockups showed that stone paper reacts more like a metal plate than a limestone, and that etching with tannic acid was most effective at stabilizing the matrix.
Data Collected (AAT): Wave-length Dispersive X-ray Fluorescence Spectroscopy (XRF); Coating
Art Historical and/or Cultural Object of: Lion Devouring a Horse by Théodore Géricault’s; Harvard Museum Collection
